node.title: The Distributional Effects of China's Economic Assistance

field_speakers.processed: Dong Zhang 張冬 (Lingnan University Hong Kong)
field_speakers.value: Dong Zhang 張冬 (Lingnan University Hong Kong)

field_organizers.processed: 21st Century China Center, UC San Diego
field_organizers.value: 21st Century China Center, UC San Diego

field_description.processed: How does an authoritarian donor's domestic political economy shape its aid practices? We probe into the case of China, the largest authoritarian donor in the world, and contend that the regime survival imperative drives China's aid policies to prioritize commercial interests and sustain the state capitalism model. By leveraging multiple data sources, we empirically document that Chinese aid projects lead to a substantial surge of Chinese exports to aid recipient countries. Perhaps more importantly, we find the aid-induced trade benefits primarily state-owned enterprises (SOEs), particularly ones that are under-performing, less productive, labor-intensive, and crippled with heavy debt burdens. The findings have important implications for understanding China's economic engagement in the world.

node.title: Book Talk: State Formation in China and Taiwan with Julia Strauss

field_speakers.processed: Julia C. Strauss (SOAS University of London)
field_speakers.value: Julia C. Strauss (SOAS University of London)

field_organizers.processed: University of Washington Taiwan Studies Program

field_description.processed: Professor Strauss' State Formation in China and Taiwan: Bureaucracy, Campaign, and Performance is a comparative study of regime consolidation in the ‘revolutionary’ People’s Republic of China and the ‘conservative’ Republic of China (Taiwan) in the years following the communist victory against the nationalists on the Chinese mainland in 1949. Julia C. Strauss argues that accounting for these two variants of the Chinese state solely in terms of their divergent ideology and institutions fails to recognize their similarities and their relative successes. Both, after all, emerged from a common background of Leninist party organization amid civil war and foreign invasion. However, by the mid-1950s they were on clearly different trajectories of state-building and development. Focusing on Sunan and Taiwan, Strauss considers state personnel, the use of terror and land reform to explore the evolution of these revolutionary and conservative regimes between 1949 and 1954.

field_speakers.processed: Javier Cha (Assistant Professor of East Asian Studies | College of Liberal Studies | Seoul National University; Visiting Scholar and Digital Historian-in-Residence | Department of History | Lingnan University)
field_speakers.value: Javier Cha (Assistant Professor of East Asian Studies | College of Liberal Studies | Seoul National University; Visiting Scholar and Digital Historian-in-Residence | Department of History | Lingnan University)

field_organizers.processed: Harvard-Yenching Library, Fairbank Center for Chinese Studies, Reischauer Institute of Japanese Studies, Korea Institute
field_organizers.value: Harvard-Yenching Library, Fairbank Center for Chinese Studies, Reischauer Institute of Japanese Studies, Korea Institute

field_description.processed: The total amount of data created by 2020, if stored in a stack of single-layer Blu-ray discs, would reach seven times the distance between the Earth and the Moon. In 2019 alone, content creators uploaded 30,000 years of video to YouTube, and Naver’s flagship data center, Kak, handles more information than ten thousand National Libraries of Korea combined. By 2025, big data will triple in size, and the COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated this growth. To meet this demand, China is aggressively increasing its data center capacity, as seen in Guizhou’s recent transformation into Big Data Valley and Alibaba Cloud’s expansion in Southeast Asia. What are the implications of this ongoing big data transformation of society in the humanities? In this talk, Javier Cha argues for the need to fundamentally rethink the humanities, from material bibliography to data analytics and cultural studies. What do we do when our sources consist of millions of servers rather than documents? How do we handle cultural artifacts that increasingly eschew text in favor of video, 3d point clouds, and holograms? Questions of this nature are at the heart of Cha’s Big Data Studies Lab at Seoul National University, which has invited librarians, historians, anthropologists, and computer scientists, among others, to search for the new normal in the humanities together. Our current proposal is to develop big data literacy and cultural data science curricula for the next generation of humanities scholars.

node.title: How Racist Rhetoric Increases Chinese Overseas Students' Support for Authoritarian Rule

field_speakers.processed: Jennifer Pan (Stanford University), Yiqing Xu (Stanford University)
field_speakers.value: Jennifer Pan (Stanford University), Yiqing Xu (Stanford University)

field_organizers.processed: Hoover Institution
field_organizers.value: Hoover Institution

field_description.processed: The cross-border flow of people for educational exchange in Western democracies is seen as a way to transfer democratic values to non-democratic regions of the world. What happens when students studying in the West encounter racism? Based on an experiment among hundreds of Chinese first-year undergraduates in the United States, we show that seeing racist, anti-Chinese rhetoric interferes with the transfer of democratic values. Chinese students who study in the United States are more predisposed to favor liberal democracy than their peers in China. However, anti-Chinese racism significantly reduces their belief that political reform is desirable for China and increases their support for authoritarian rule. These effects are most pronounced among students who are more likely to reject Chinese nationalism.Encountering non-racist criticisms of the Chinese government does not increase support for authoritarianism.

field_description.processed: The history of treatments for diseases by Chinese "Traditional Chinese medicine" (TCM) drugs is very long. Compared with Euro-centred "western" biomedical drugs, the multiple chemical components of TCM drugs are complex; and multiple targets just as molecular mechanisms are not clear. The drugs’ pharmaceutical actions have mainly been induced from documented experience. In recent years, the rise of the concept of multi-target drugs and advances in modernization of TCM drugs have accelerated research on the actions and mechanisms of TCM drugs. Our research will illustrate the effects of TCM drugs on diseases through the acquisition of information on the active ingredients of TCM drugs, through identification of the pharmaceutical materials’ targets, and through our mapping of the regulated metabolic and our determination of disease pathways modified and controlled by the TCM drugs.

CEAS Author Talks series, this event features California College of the Arts Professor, Mia Yinxing Liu, and her book, "Literati Lenses: Wenren Landscape in Chinese Cinema of the Mao Era," Since its birth, Chinese cinema has been exploring the ways to engage with China’s art
traditions, and these engagements can range from violently iconoclastic to devotedly reverential. node.title: Composing Courtesy: Understanding Envoy Poetry in Early Modern East Asia

field_speakers.processed: Dr. Wiebke Denecke (Massachusetts Institute of Technology)
field_speakers.value: Dr. Wiebke Denecke (Massachusetts Institute of Technology)

field_organizers.processed: Centre for Chinese Research at the University of British Columbia (UBC), Centre for Korean Research (UBC), Centre for Japanese Research (UBC), University of British Columbia
field_organizers.value: Centre for Chinese Research at the University of British Columbia (UBC), Centre for Korean Research (UBC), Centre for Japanese Research (UBC), University of British Columbia

field_description.processed: This talk focuses on envoy poetry from early modern East Asia, in particular on Collections of Magnificent Flowers (Hwanghwajip), a large corpus of officially compiled poetry anthologies from the missions the Ming court sent to Chosŏn Korea between 1450 and 1633; and several 18th-century poetry collections from Korea’s t'ongsinsa missions to Japan. In cross-cultural perspective East Asia’s envoy poetry is a highly distinctive phenomenon: during their encounters envoys communicated in the scripta (rather than lingua) franca of Literary Sinitic through “brush talk” on paper; they were Confucian literati eager to display their talent in collective poetry composition on set topics and shared rhyme schemes; and they learnt how to play with a common set of themes and tropes to convey courtesy and conviviality.

field_description.processed:
Is China or the U.S. ahead in artificial intelligence? What is the best way to counter security threats in 5G technology? How do we best maintain American leadership positions in fundamental research and biotechnology?

These and other questions about a new strategy for U.S.-China competition in science and technology will be addressed in the press conference as we launch a policy report on "Meeting the China Challenge: A New American Strategy for Technology Competition."

The report is the culmination of over a full year’s deliberation and study by the Working Group on Science and Technology in U.S.-China Relations. It sets forth broad policy objectives as well as specific recommendations for the new U.S. administration in four domains of science and technology: fundamental research, 5G digital communications, artificial intelligence and biotechnology.

node.title: Documentary Photography and Social Engagement in China Today: Navigating in Troubled Waters

field_organizers.processed: East Asian Studies, Johns Hopkins University
field_organizers.value: East Asian Studies, Johns Hopkins University

field_description.processed: The evolution—and survival—of documentary photography in China has been contingent and vulnerable, even as it has offered powerful and urgent commentary on contemporary issues. Photographers face high risks as they navigate politically treacherous waters. How have the lines between social and political issues been affected by the rise of the market economy and the fluctuation of regime politics? What kind of strategic interactions can be found among photographers, societal actors, market actors, and bureaucrats? This talk will explore these dynamics by examining the works and personal stories of some of the most influential documentary photographers active in China today.

node.title: China and England: the Preindustrial Struggle for Justice in Word and Image

field_speakers.processed: Martin Powers (University of Michigan)
field_speakers.value: Martin Powers (University of Michigan)

field_organizers.processed: University of Chicago Center for East Asian Studies
field_organizers.value: University of Chicago Center for East Asian Studies

field_description.processed: Part of the East Asia by the Book! CEAS Author Talks series, this event features University of Michigan Professor Martin Powers, and his book, "China and England: the Preindustrial Struggle for Justice in Word and Image." Professor Powers examines egalitarian social ideals and institutions that arose in preindustrial China and England, and in the process, uncovers China’s forgotten role in the history of social justice debate and legislation during the eighteenth century. Drawing on a wide range of visual and documentary evidence, the author shows that many prominent individuals in both England and China adopted comparable strategies as a logical response to excesses of privilege and arbitrary power, with educated but non-noble persons taking advantage of print culture, a more literate population, an expanded art market, public spaces and other familiar ‘early modern’ developments to interrogate the system of inherited privilege and promote a more meritocratic society.

node.title: Debt at a Distance: China’s Debt Collection Callers during Covid-19

field_speakers.processed: Dr. Tom McDonald (Department of Sociology, The University of Hong Kong)
field_speakers.value: Dr. Tom McDonald (Department of Sociology, The University of Hong Kong)

field_organizers.processed: Hong Kong Institute for the Humanities and Social Sciences, The University of Hong Kong
field_organizers.value: Hong Kong Institute for the Humanities and Social Sciences, The University of Hong Kong

field_description.processed: During the early stages of China’s Covid-19 outbreak — which happened to coincide with the nation’s Spring Festival celebrations — severe restrictions on nationwide travel were enacted, leaving millions numbers of workers stuck in their hometowns and unable to return to their workplaces. Many workers faced an unexpected shortfall in their earnings and as a result missed repayments on loans and credit cards. This paper examines how China’s financial institutions and debt collection agencies attempted to enforce debts “from a distance” during this period, along with debtors’ responses to these efforts. We document how both parties’ actions were framed by broader ongoing regulatory shifts whereby the state has aimed to ‘civilise’ debt collection in China. We ask what the implications of cold calling, debt collection scripts, automated messaging and Artificial Intelligence had for the moral performativity of debt collection and repayment?

field_speakers.processed: Elbridge Colby (The Marathon Initiative and former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy and Force Development), Shelley Rigger (Davidson College), Deepa Ollapally (Rising Powers Initiative & Sigur Center for Asian Studies)
field_speakers.value: Elbridge Colby (The Marathon Initiative and former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Strategy and Force Development), Shelley Rigger (Davidson College), Deepa Ollapally (Rising Powers Initiative & Sigur Center for Asian Studies)

field_organizers.processed: Sigur Center for Asian Studies, George Washington University
field_organizers.value: Sigur Center for Asian Studies, George Washington University

field_description.processed:
Chinese pressure on Taiwan during these unprecedented pandemic times has been ratcheting up, not down. This is leading to more cross-Strait tension than ever, raising concerns about Taiwan’s ability to defend itself. Against the unsettled backdrop of COVID-19, panelists will discuss cross-Strait military balance, the impact of deteriorating US-China relations, the October 2020 arms sales to Taiwan, and the changing political attitudes and strategy in Taiwan toward China. And what are some preliminary speculations on the impact of US election results on these issues?

Elbridge Colby will comment on "The cross-Strait Military Situation: Challenges and Considerations for US Policy for the Next Four Years," while Shelley Rigger will speak on "How Taiwan's Changing Domestic Scene is Shaping cross-Strait Relations."

The discussion will be moderated by Deepa Ollapally, Associate Director of the Sigur Center, and the event will feature an extensive period for audience Q&A.

node.title: Contesting Eco-urbanism from Below: The Construction of ‘Zero-waste Neighbourhoods’ in Contemporary Chinese Cities

field_speakers.processed: Shih-yang Kao (Xi’an Jiaotong-Liverpool University)
field_speakers.value: Shih-yang Kao (Xi’an Jiaotong-Liverpool University)

field_organizers.processed: MIT Sustainable Urbanization Lab
field_organizers.value: MIT Sustainable Urbanization Lab

field_description.processed: How should we understand the recent rapid spread of eco‐urbanism around the world and its move into the mainstream? This understanding has become increasingly dominated by narratives of the urban sustainability fix, which stresses the logic of capital accumulation. Within the broader structural processes of ecological modernization (e.g., low‐carbon growth), consideration of—let alone interest in—the diversity of local politics that shapes the practice and forms of contestation of eco‐urbanism has often been relegated to a position of secondary importance. Drawing on a detailed case study of the prevalence of zero‐waste neighborhood experiments in many Chinese cities, this article underscores the potential of grassroots activism to change the nature, dynamics and landscape of eco‐urbanism significantly. It calls for a new understanding of eco‐urbanism: one which is more attentive to the diversity, heterogeneity and contextual sensitivity of urban change at the grassroots level.

field_description.processed: East Asian social welfare systems have been traditionally described as productivist regimes in which most social investments focus on elements of welfare that can induce economic growth. Extant East Asian welfare comparative research often focuses on a limited set of social policies and seldom captures the bundle of welfare programs or the contexts in which these programs operate (e.g., tax systems and service costs). This study extends the understanding of East Asian welfare systems by comparing social safety nets in mainland China, Hong Kong, Japan, Singapore, South Korea, and Taiwan using a model family approach. This study’s findings can contribute to the debate on the contemporary landscape of East Asian welfare models and inform policymakers in East Asia of the strengths of social safety nets in their countries relative to others.

field_organizers.value: The Society for Chinese Law and Black Voices on Greater China at Columbia Law School

field_description.processed: Extensive engagement between China and African countries has produced vast exchanges in goods and personnel over the decades. In 2012, it was estimated that more than 100,000 Africans lived in the southern city of Guangzhou, China. Nevertheless, Black communities in China have long reported inconsistent immigration law enforcement and racial profiling, an issue that has come under the spotlight since the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic. Recent months saw increased reports of random passport inspections, incidents of housing discrimination, and arbitrary detainment. In response, the Chinese government claims to be addressing illegal entry of foreigners and “imported” cases of Covid-19. Such incidents have drawn the attention of commentators across the globe to the treatment of African migrant workers by law enforcement. This panel will explore how China’s work visa policies impact African workers currently in or hoping to enter China in today's context.

field_description.processed: Since the beginning of the reform era in 1978, the decreasing importance of ideology and the alternative career options provided by a liberalized employment market have made the Chinese Party-State’s ability to attract recruits and maintain their commitment all the more puzzling. If ideology and material gain cannot fully account for it, what motivates young Chinese’s commitment to a long-term career in the party-state? This talk tackles this question by analyzing the first steps of political professionalization in the CCP’s youth organizations and unveiling the crucial role these institutions play in political recruitment.

node.title: Rural Development in China and East Asia

field_speakers.processed: Kristen Looney (Georgetown University), Meg Rithmire (Harvard Business School)
field_speakers.value: Kristen Looney (Georgetown University), Meg Rithmire (Harvard Business School)

field_organizers.processed: Harvard University Fairbank Center For Chinese Studies
field_organizers.value: Harvard University Fairbank Center For Chinese Studies

field_description.processed: This talk tackles the question of how countries achieve rural development and offers a new way of thinking about East Asia’s political economy that challenges the developmental state paradigm. Through a comparison of Taiwan (1950s–1970s), South Korea (1950s–1970s), and China (1980s–2000s), Kristen E. Looney shows that different types of development outcomes—improvements in agricultural production, rural living standards, and the village environment—were realized to different degrees, at different times, and in different ways. She argues that rural modernization campaigns, defined as policies demanding high levels of mobilization to effect dramatic change, played a central role in the region and that divergent development outcomes can be attributed to the interplay between campaigns and institutions.

node.title: USC-CCS China Studies Webinar Series: Molihua [茉莉花] as Cultural Text: what can music bring to Chinese Studies

field_speakers.processed: Professor Frederick LAU, Department of Music, CUHK
field_speakers.value: Professor Frederick LAU, Department of Music, CUHK

field_organizers.processed: Universities Service Centre for China Studies and Centre for China Studies, CUHK
field_organizers.value: Universities Service Centre for China Studies and Centre for China Studies, CUHK

field_description.processed: Molihua is a Chinese folksong known throughout China and in the world. Why does a humble regional folksong attain such global notoriety?  In this talk, I discuss several important moments of this folksong’s existence.  I describe the different ways that Molihu has been received, recontextualized, resignfied, and capitalized inside and outside China. Its journey took the song from China to England, Japan, Europe, and eventually turned it into the best-known Chinese folksong abroad.  It has also been transformed into a musical and cultural icon for many China musicians and composers at home nowadays.  Using Molihua as a text and case study, I suggest that music and sonic articulation are important tools for understanding the sentiment and the everchanging modes of circulation of Chinese music.  The shifting meaning of Molihua reveals how China has been perceived, performed, and construed by both insiders and outsiders.

node.title: Riskier than you think: Crisis instability between the US and China in maritime Asia

field_speakers.processed: Peter Dombrowski (US Naval War College), Jonathan D. Caverley (US Naval War College)
field_speakers.value: Peter Dombrowski (US Naval War College), Jonathan D. Caverley (US Naval War College)

field_organizers.processed: University of Oxford China Centre
field_organizers.value: University of Oxford China Centre

field_description.processed:
The mainstream position is that a combination of technology and strategy is pushing us to a world where crises in maritime Asia will be more stable, taking the form of a defensive standoff. We believe that view is overly optimistic, for it overlooks how operational culture, bureaucratic incentives, and the temptation to strike first are creating the circumstances for a perfect storm. In our talk, we will outline what the dangers are and why we need to pay more attention to them.
Jonathan D. Caverley is Professor of Strategy in the Strategic & Operational Research Department of the Naval War College’s Center for Naval Warfare Studies and a Research Scientist in Political Science and Security Studies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Dr Peter Dombrowski is the William D. Ruger Chair of National Security Economics Strategic and Operational Research Department at the Naval War College.

field_description.processed: In 2020, as COVID-19 swept the globe, award-winning documentary filmmakers Yung Chang and Hao Wu each co-directed landmark films exploring the outbreak in Wuhan, China. Backed by an A-list production team, including Oscar-winning producer Donna Gigliotti (Hidden Figures, Shakespeare in Love), and actor star Donnie Yen (Yip Man, Mulan), Wuhan! Wuhan! Is co-directed by Gong Cheng and Yung Chang. Following 36 hours in the lives of several individuals during the outbreak, Wuhan! Wuhan! offers a rare glimpse into the early days of coronavirus outbreak in China. Hao Wu’s 76 Days, co-directed by Weixi Chen and anonymous, focuses on a broader time frame, offering glimpses into the entire 76 day lockdown through the eyes of patients and medical workers. This event will bring two of the most exciting documentary filmmakers of their generation, in dialogue with Michael Berry (CCS Director and translator of Wuhan Diary), to discuss their experience documenting the early stage of a global pandemic.

field_speakers.value: Xingyi Wang (PhD Candidate at Harvard University)

field_organizers.processed: Harvard University Fairbank Center For Chinese Studies
field_organizers.value: Harvard University Fairbank Center For Chinese Studies

field_description.processed: This talk focuses on the practice of robing monastics in the Vinaya revival in Song China and Kamakura Japan. The formative power of the Vinaya on the individual body and on the collective community hinges on the mediacy of the robe. By tracing the trajectory of the commentarial tradition and material culture of the Vinaya from Song China to Kamakura Japan, I show how Buddhists negotiated the tension between fidelity to the Vinaya and their localized ephemeral social reality.

node.title: Divining the Future and Averting Misfortune in Japan: The Case of Shugendō

field_speakers.processed: George Klonos (East Asian Religions; IKGF Visiting Fellow)
field_speakers.value: George Klonos (East Asian Religions; IKGF Visiting Fellow)

field_organizers.processed: International Research Consortium “Fate, Freedom, and Prognostication — Strategies for Coping with the Future in East Asia and Europe," University of Erlangen–Nuremberg
field_organizers.value: International Research Consortium “Fate, Freedom, and Prognostication — Strategies for Coping with the Future in East Asia and Europe," University of Erlangen–Nuremberg

field_description.processed:
Shugendō 修験道, the tradition of Japanese mountain asceticism, was ubiquitous in Japanese religious life, its patrons and clientele ranging from courtiers and warriors to farmers and city dwellers. Its adherents used their powers to provide services such as healing, exorcisms, and talismans.
The study of Shugendō reveals a tradition rich in Esoteric Buddhist doctrine and ritual, although distinct from the Tendai 天台 and Shingon 真言 schools most often associated with Japanese Esoteric Buddhism. The present talk introduces ritual methods from collections of kirigami 切紙, texts composed in the early modern period (1600–1868), which deal with subjects such as childbirth, protection from wild animals and spirits, epidemics, protection from bandits, fires, dreams.
This ritual technology adapted both Indian (dhāraṇī, Siddhaṃ 悉曇 script) and Chinese (five phases, trigrams, branches and stems) systems of knowledge, combining them to produce methods in which both sound (speech) and image are important

node.title: Politics of Love: Religion, Secularism, and Love as Political Discourse in Modern China

field_speakers.processed: Guo TING
field_speakers.value: Guo TING

field_organizers.processed: Lancaster University China Centre
field_organizers.value: Lancaster University China Centre

field_description.processed: This talk examines how the concept of ai (love) as an affective notion has been introduced, adapted and engineered for the building and rebuilding of a modern nation. I will look into the different adaptations and usages of ai by China’s political leaders, in order to reveal the versatile nature of love as a critical mechanism within modern Chinese politics. Rather than studying love in the private realm such as romance, relationship, and family, this project studies love as a public discourse, and political discourse to be more precise, for it is the very word ai that has been more commonly adopted as a political discourse, including aiguo (patriotism), you’ai (friendship) and re’ai (ardent love).

node.title: Contested Urban Space in China’s Capital City during the Fortieth Year of the People’s Republic

field_speakers.processed: Jeremy Brown (Simon Fraser University)
field_speakers.value: Jeremy Brown (Simon Fraser University)

field_organizers.processed: MIT
field_organizers.value: MIT

field_description.processed: To ensure that everyone who wants to attend this talk can do so, this abstract is intentionally abstract. Rest assured that the talk itself will be clear and specific. How people use and interact with each other in urban space changes during periods of protest and during crackdowns against protesters, as we have seen in recent months in such American cities as Portland, Oregon, and Washington, DC. This phenomenon also occurred in China’s capital during the fortieth year of the People’s Republic, when previously formal and somber spaces became sites of spontaneous joy, and when such mundane urban activities as commuting to work or going to a pharmacy for medicine became life-threatening. This talk draws on material from my forthcoming book to analyze how people’s lives changed when the nature of urban space suddenly shifted. I also discuss how events in China’s capital in the fortieth year of the People’s Republic affected (or did not affect) rural people.

node.title: Readership in Maoist China's Context of Heightened Political Controls

field_speakers.processed: Peidong Sun (CERI, Science Po Paris), Puck Engman (University of Freiburg/UC Berkeley)
field_speakers.value: Peidong Sun (CERI, Science Po Paris), Puck Engman (University of Freiburg/UC Berkeley)

field_organizers.processed: European Research Council, University of Freiburg, ReadChina Team
field_organizers.value: European Research Council, University of Freiburg, ReadChina Team

field_description.processed: Politics has always had an impact on readership in a given society. In the Maoist China, the degree of political controls over the practices of reading and communication becomes particularly intense. The third session of the ReadChina Freiburg online lecture series, "Practices of Reading in the PRC", will reach this topic from the angles of the receivers and the reception/dissemination processes of political forces. The first talk, given by Dr. Peidong Sun, discusses the state censorship on personal readings during the Cultural Revolution, with further suggestions on the limitations of censorship in the everyday life and reading. The second talk, given by Dr. Puck Engman, suggests an understanding of political communication in a context of “decoding.” A top-secret bulletin for the political elites will be discussed as a case, with a focus on how the intelligence provided through this bulletin is circulated and consumed.

node.title: Invisible China: How the Urban-Rural Divide Threatens China’s Rise

field_speakers.processed: Scott Rozelle, Freeman Spogli Institute at Stanford University
field_speakers.value: Scott Rozelle, Freeman Spogli Institute at Stanford University

field_organizers.processed: Australian Centre on China in the World, The Australian National University
field_organizers.value: Australian Centre on China in the World, The Australian National University

field_description.processed: As the glittering skyline in Shanghai seemingly attests, China has quickly transformed itself from a place of stark poverty into a modern, urban, technologically savvy economic powerhouse. As Scott Rozelle and Natalie Hell show in "Invisible China: How the Urban-Rural Divide Threatens China’s Rise", the truth is more complicated and might be a serious cause for concern. China’s growth has relied heavily on unskilled labor. While this national growth strategy has been effective for three decades, the unskilled wage rate has been rising for more than a decade. Rozelle and Hell speak not only to an urgent humanitarian concern but also a potential economic crisis that could upend economies and foreign relations around the globe. If too many are left structurally unemployable, the implications both inside and outside of China could be serious.

field_speakers.processed: Dr. Kyle Haddad-Fonda (Fellow, Foreign Policy Association)
field_speakers.value: Dr. Kyle Haddad-Fonda (Fellow, Foreign Policy Association)

field_organizers.processed: Hong Kong Institute for the Humanities and Social Sciences, The University of Hong Kong
field_organizers.value: Hong Kong Institute for the Humanities and Social Sciences, The University of Hong Kong

field_description.processed: Throughout its existence, the People’s Republic of China has depended on Chinese Muslims to foster relationships in the Arab world. But Beijing’s strategies for engaging its Muslim population in foreign outreach have changed dramatically over time. This lecture will focus on the city of Yinchuan, the capital of China’s Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, which was built up during the 2010s to be a locus for engagement with the Middle East. By tracing Yinchuan’s ups and downs over the past decade, this lecture will explain the evolution of China’s diplomacy toward the Middle East and examine the ways in which China continues to rely on Islam, even at a time when religiosity in China is more contentious than ever before.

node.title: Tchang's Secret Signature: Paranoia, Realism, and The Adventures of Tintin

field_speakers.processed: Andrew F. Jones (University of California, Berkeley)
field_speakers.value: Andrew F. Jones (University of California, Berkeley)

field_organizers.processed: University of Oxford China Centre
field_organizers.value: University of Oxford China Centre

field_description.processed: This talk traces the artistic collaboration of Hergé, the Belgian comic book artist and author of The Adventures of Tintin, with the prominent Chinese painter and sculptor Zhang Chongren 張充仁. Tchang (as he was known in French) is not only the central character in two of Hergé’s best loved albums, Le Lotus Bleu and Tintin au Tibet, but also the catalyst for Hergé’s own unlikely transformation from his origins as far-right Belgian Catholic royalist, colonial apologist, and crude caricaturist, to the avatar of a new realism in the realm of the comics, characterized by meticulous research, and the precise mimetic rendering of the many exotic locales in which the adventures of Tintin and his trusty terrier Milou unfold.

node.title: Podcasting Chinese Lives: In Conversation with Story FM

field_speakers.processed: Kou Aizhe (Gushi FM)
field_speakers.value: Kou Aizhe (Gushi FM)

field_organizers.processed: University of Glasgow
field_organizers.value: University of Glasgow

field_description.processed:
In China's complex and saturated media landscape, Gushi FM stands out as an unlikely success story. After starting in 2017, Gushi FM (or Story FM) is now one of China’s most popular podcasts, averaging over half a million listeners per episode. In each episode, an individual tells a personal story from their own point of view, often blurring the lines between the remarkable and the everyday.

Kou Aizhe is the creator of Gushi FM. He now leads a team producing three stories a week. He previously worked as a journalist in the Chinese media and with Swedish and Canadian broadcasters. In this event, Kou Aizhe will talk about his work with Gushi FM and how he tells the stories of others in his podcasts.
This event will followed by Q&A.

node.title: Revolution in the Nation of Poetry: Physical and Linguistic Perspectives since 1919 詩國革命的「漢語」脈絡

field_speakers.processed: Cheng Yu-yu (National Taiwan University)
field_speakers.value: Cheng Yu-yu (National Taiwan University)

field_organizers.processed: Harvard University Fairbank Center For Chinese Studies
field_organizers.value: Harvard University Fairbank Center For Chinese Studies

field_description.processed: Once Chinese poetry becomes “modern poetry,” its so-called modernity must be discussed in the context of the modernity of “Chinese language” itself. From the late Qing and early Republican periods on, when confronted with the invasion of such things as new lexicon, new academic disciplines, alphabetic languages, and English grammar, the Chinese language, Chinese characters, and the cultural tradition to which it belongs have never ceased responding to and reflecting upon such foreign forces. In examining this “modernizing” process of Chinese poetry, which progressed from the question of “how to speak to the new world” to that of “how to reestablish a new relationship with the world,” one cannot overlook the new ways of thinking of the Chinese language that emerged from and were constructed by various disciplines, including grammatology, philology, phonology, psychology, and rhetoric studies.

field_description.processed:
How to assess the challenges and opportunities for Hong Kong and China given the conspicuous conflicts as witnessed in the unrest of 2019?

This seminar contextualizes the inquiry through the historical vision of the One Country, Two Systems framework, the Belt and Road Initiative promoted by the current Chinese leadership, and its Plan for the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macau Greater Bay Area, the latter unveiled shortly before the eruption of 2019 conflicts. The tested practice to leverage on institutional contradictions for change and reform will be reviewed alongside escalating challenges to stay close to the path.

node.title: Ritual Time, Secular Democracy: On Literary Depictions of Chinese and Indian Popular Religions in Malaysia

field_speakers.processed: Dr. Nicholas Y. H. Wong (Society of Fellows in the Humanities, The University of Hong Kong)
field_speakers.value: Dr. Nicholas Y. H. Wong (Society of Fellows in the Humanities, The University of Hong Kong)

field_organizers.processed: Hong Kong Institute for the Humanities and Social Sciences, The University of Hong Kong
field_organizers.value: Hong Kong Institute for the Humanities and Social Sciences, The University of Hong Kong

field_description.processed: Though inadequate, popular religion has been an outsourced space for democratic participation. In Malaysia, the street procession’s carnivalesque inversion of order allows ethnic groups to mingle and participate in each other’s rituals beyond the state’s Malay-Muslim ethnocracy. In this talk, I discuss Mahua (or Chinese-Malaysian) descriptions of spectatorship and spirit mediumship in religious processions, such as the Nine Emperor Gods Festival (Taoist) and Thaipusam (Hindu). What aspects are highlighted and to what ends? What ritual aspects evolved from the intertwined histories of Chinese and Indian migrant communities that worked at tin mines and rubber plantations? I argue that Mahua authors, in their secular literary texts, piously channel a pantheon of gods to propose their versions of dharma (law) and reciprocity in the context of modern democracy or, as Étienne Balibar calls it, the “constitution of citizenship.”

field_description.processed: Different from the privatized view of reading, in the Chinese cultural field, reading through a certain medium or of a certain artistic form often binds the individual to macroscopic social programs and to the politics of the everyday. In the fourth session of the online lecture series "Practices of Reading in the People's Republic of China", Haiyan Zhou will discuss how the reading of images of labor are linked to the broader image of the global socialist movement presented in newspapers in the 1950s China. The other speaker, Benjamin Kindler, will then discuss the practices of the Chinese literary form “short short story” across a long historical arc, highlighting the extend to which this form dislocates reading from its location in an individual subject, makes room for collective reading, and transforms the contents of everyday life. Prof. Robert Culp (Bard College) will be acting as discussant to this session.

field_description.processed:
Australia’s relationships with the various nations of Asia are complex—the current trade and diplomatic crisis with China shows us the speed at which gains made over years can unravel in a matter of months. This crisis emerged despite more than 30 years of initiatives designed to improve Australia’s knowledge of Asia and reorient our thinking. Australians often struggle to really see, speak or listen to Asia.

The 2020 China in the World Annual lecture asks: How does “Asia” manifest in Australia? How does our current crisis with China reflect deeper problems in Australia’s engagement with Asia and Asian Australians?

Louise Edwards is Scientia Professor of Chinese History at UNSW, Sydney and Honorary Professor at Hong Kong University’s China Studies program. She teaches on China and Asia-Australia relations. Edwards is a Fellow of the Australian Academy of Humanities, the Academy of the Social Sciences in Australia and the Hong Kong Academy of the Humanities.

node.title: Moving Chairs in Starbucks: How Rice Farming Made Southern China More Interdependent Than the North

field_speakers.processed: Thomas Talhelm (University of Chicago Booth School of Business)
field_speakers.value: Thomas Talhelm (University of Chicago Booth School of Business)

field_organizers.processed: University of Chicago Center for East Asian Studies
field_organizers.value: University of Chicago Center for East Asian Studies

field_description.processed: Growing rice is very different from growing wheat. Traditional paddy rice required about twice as many labor hours as wheat, which led rice farmers to share labor. Paddy rice also relied on irrigation networks, which require farmers to coordinate their water use and flood their fields at the same time. These elements gave rice villages a dense social world, with tight social ties. Across four studies, I test thousands of people’s thought style and behavior across China. The data shows that these patterns of behavioral differences fall along the historical borders of rice and wheat—even in modern day Starbucks.

field_description.processed: In the history of medicine in China, the medical officers to the Chinese Imperial Maritime Customs Service and medical missionaries play a pivotal role in the development of modern medicine. As well as founding hospitals and medical schools the medical customs officers' and missionaries's efforts in knowledge production were also a key driving force behind the development of modern medicine in China during the late Qing period. Among such efforts, the publication of Medical Reports and the China Medical Journal was the most representative. They became landmarks in the history of modern medicine in China. This study examines the production of knowledge among the medical communities of foreign doctors during the late Qing period by applying the approach of natural language processing in digital humanities to analysing Medical Reports and the China Medical Journal.

node.title: Supporting the Faith, Building the Empire: Imperial Japan’s Islamic Policies in World War II

field_speakers.processed: Dr. Kelly Hammond (University of Arkansas)
field_speakers.value: Dr. Kelly Hammond (University of Arkansas)

field_organizers.processed: Hong Kong Institute for the Humanities and Social Sciences, The University of Hong Kong
field_organizers.value: Hong Kong Institute for the Humanities and Social Sciences, The University of Hong Kong

field_description.processed: This talk will examine some of the ways that the Japanese Empire curried favors to Muslims in China, and later throughout East Asia, in the lead up to and throughout World War II. Drawing on examples from my recent book, China’s Muslims and Japan’s Empire: Centering Islam in World War II, the talk will present viewers with concrete policies and explore some of the ways that the Japanese Government envisioned themselves as the benevolent protectors of Islam while at the same time advancing their imperial, expansionist visions. For their part, Muslims from around the colonial world found the anti-western and anti-Soviet rhetoric expounded by the Japanese Empire appealing to a certain extent. By placing Muslims at the center of Japan’s imperial ambitions, it becomes clear that their visions for empire went far beyond what we would now consider to be the geographic boundaries of the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere into predominantly Islamic spaces.

field_speakers.processed: Professor Robert Cliver (Professor of History, Humboldt State University)
field_speakers.value: Professor Robert Cliver (Professor of History, Humboldt State University)

field_organizers.value: Hong Kong Institute for the Humanities and Social Sciences, The University of Hong Kong

field_description.processed: Red Silk (Harvard University Asia Center, 2020) is a history of China’s Yangzi Delta silk industry during the wars, crises, and revolutions of the mid-twentieth century. Based on extensive research in Chinese archives and focused on the 1950s, the book compares two very different groups of silk workers and their experiences in the revolution. Male silk weavers in Shanghai factories enjoyed close ties to the Communist party-state and benefited greatly from socialist policies after 1949. In contrast, workers in silk thread mills, or filatures, were mostly young women who lacked powerful organizations or ties to the revolutionary regime. For many filature workers, working conditions changed little after 1949 and politicized production campaigns added a new burden within the brutal and oppressive factory regime in place since the nineteenth century.

field_description.processed: A Eurasian transformation is underway, and it flows from China. With a geopolitically central location, the country’s domestic and international policies are poised to change the face of global affairs. The Belt and Road Initiative has called attention to a deepening Eurasian continentalism that has, argues Kent Calder, much more significant implications than have yet been recognized. He shows that key inflection points, beginning with the Four Modernizations and the collapse of the Soviet Union; and culminating in China’s response to the Global Financial Crisis and Crimea’s annexation, are triggering tectonic shifts.

node.title: Calculating Bully - Explaining Chinese Coercion

field_speakers.processed: Ketian Vivian Zhang (George Mason University)
field_speakers.value: Ketian Vivian Zhang (George Mason University)

field_organizers.processed: University of Oxford China Centre
field_organizers.value: University of Oxford China Centre

field_description.processed: Since 1990, China has used coercion for territorial disputes, foreign arms sales to Taiwan, and foreign leaders’ meetings with the Dalai Lama, despite adverse implications for its international image. China is also curiously selective in the timing, target, and tools of coercion: most cases of Chinese coercion are not military coercion, nor does China coerce all states that pose the same threats to its national security. Prof. Zhang's book manuscript, Calculating Bully – Explaining Chinese Coercion, examines when, why, and how China coerces states when faced with threats to its national security. It asks two central questions: when and why does China coerce, and – if coercion is chosen – what tools does China use? Ketian Vivian Zhang is an Assistant Professor of International Security in the Schar School of Policy and Government, George Mason University.

node.title: Does Chinese foreign behavior warrant sustained US countermeasures?

field_speakers.processed: Robert Sutter (George Washington University)
field_speakers.value: Robert Sutter (George Washington University)

field_organizers.processed: Sigur Center for Asian Studies at George Washington University
field_organizers.value: Sigur Center for Asian Studies at George Washington University

field_description.processed:
A lecture launching Chinese Foreign Relations: Power and Policy of an Emerging Global Force, 5th edition, with author Robert Sutter.
Dealing with assertive China was the most prominent foreign policy issue in the 2020 presidential election campaign and the debate remains acute. Advocates of hard countermeasures toward China say previous US administrations’ failure to counter Chinese challenges resulted in China now posing an enormous danger to American interests. Critics play down past failures and dangers posed by China, condemn excesses in the recent US hard-line, and favor a more moderate and nuanced approach. Robert Sutter’s fifth edition overhauls previous editions to offer a comprehensive evidence-based assessment of Chinese foreign behavior to conclude that the United States, its allies and partners are fundamentally challenged by wide-ranging and intensifying Chinese efforts to weaken America in headlong pursuit of ever expanding Chinese ambitions.

node.title: Reading acts and Maoist China’s Rural Area

field_speakers.processed: Emily Graf (Free University of Berlin), Sisi Dong (Minnan Normal University)
field_speakers.value: Emily Graf (Free University of Berlin), Sisi Dong (Minnan Normal University)

field_organizers.processed: European Research Council, University of Freiburg, ReadChina research team
field_organizers.value: European Research Council, University of Freiburg, ReadChina research team

field_description.processed: As a site of reading and of its various representations, rural China has its own contexts and aspects. Nevertheless, the rural was of great significance for various reading-related campaigns and political movements of the Maoist state. In the fifth session of the ReadChina lecture series "Practices of Reading in PRC", Emily Graf focuses on “barefoot doctors” in the countryside in relation to reading. By investigating their double roles as both the subject of reading acts and the depicted objects in the representations of reading, Graf shows how barefoot doctors engaged in world-making practices, and asserted their place in a newly mapped world of revolutionary health. Sisi Dong will then discuss the Campaign to Study Mao Zedong's Works in southwestern China's rural societies. Focusing on a small village in Fujian province, Dong analyses the concrete reading situations, related difficulties and corresponding methods to deal with them, as well as the historical impact of the campaign.

node.title: Inner Mongolia: Three Words in the Wake of a Broken Strike

field_speakers.processed: Christopher P. Atwood
field_speakers.value: Christopher P. Atwood

field_organizers.processed: Australian Centre on China in the World, the Australian National University
field_organizers.value: Australian Centre on China in the World, the Australian National University

field_description.processed: In response to a new school policy, Mongols in Inner Mongolia erupted in a social media storm, defending their mother tongue. The social media storm evolved into a student-teacher strike that rocked the region. The Inner Mongolian authorities had been trying to ease the policy in quietly, even covertly, and at first reacted with hesitation. Pushed into action by Beijing, they quickly rallied and moved into action, coaxing and corralling the students, teachers, and parents into line. Within a few weeks, at the cost of numerous arrests, firings, and up to eight suicides by Mongols caught between the demands of the power vertical and their sense of community responsibility, the strike was broken and the policy forced through. All is back to normal, at least on the surface. But the arguments that spilled out online remain with the questions the definition: what happened? And what did it mean? This talk will attempt to understand the rhetoric in terms of three contested terms.

field_description.processed: Taking as a starting point PRC President Xi Jinping’s dictum to “Tell China’s Story Well” (2013), this lecture seeks to observe the multiple attempts to tell the “China story” since the millennial turn. At a time when both “history” and “story” are incorporated into the truth regime of the state, fiction is now, more than ever, a highly contested form in manifesting the power of polyphony. The speaker will discuss three of 'the most exciting' aspects of contemporary fiction in the Chinese and Sinophone world via three related terms: transgression, transmigration, and transillumination; and ponder their political and ethical implications.

node.title: The Third Force and exiled Chinese intellectuals in Hong Kong: 1950-1963

field_speakers.processed: Professor Angela Chin (Pomona College)
field_speakers.value: Professor Angela Chin (Pomona College)

field_organizers.processed: UCLA Asia Pacific Center
field_organizers.value: UCLA Asia Pacific Center

field_description.processed: The Third Force is a political movement based in Hong Kong during the Cold War era. Formed primarily by male intellectuals who escaped to Hong Kong in the late 1940s, the alliance relied on overseas connections, using limited funds to operate publications and arrange meetings. Members shared disillusionment with both the CCP and the GMD and perceived the colonized city of Hong Kong as a refuge in which they could organize dissident political activities and articulate their visions for a better China. These activists seldom referred to Hong Kong as their “home.” Examining the Third Force's publications, this presentation analyzes how Hong Kong functioned as an international production center for cultural and political critiques of China. Although the movement only had few tangible political accomplishments before its disappearance in the mid-1960s, its work in shaping the diasporic aspirations for democracy inspired the minds of future generations of activists in Hong Kong and abroad.

field_description.processed: You are cordially invited to join us for the Contemporary China Research Cluster Public Lecture - China and the Problem of Influence in International Relations. China’s re-emergence over the last few decades meant its growing influence has been felt across many dimensions by both its regional neighbors and other states. China is reshaping its relationships throughout Asia and beyond as it engages economically, diplomatically, culturally, and militarily. In recent years, critical questions on the “rise of China” have extended to concerns over whether China’s leaders will seek to alter the system in ways that favor their interests, and whether and at what point they will have the wherewithal to effect such changes. In this lecture, Professor Goh will focus on the problems of studying China’s influence in international relations.

field_organizers.processed: Department of Politics and Public Administration, University of Hong Kong

field_description.processed: You are cordially invited to join us for the Contemporary China Research Cluster Public Lecture - Mind the Gap: Analytical Challenges to Studying China’s or Any Other Country’s Influence. In this lecture, Professor Chan will present cautionary remarks and illustrative examples suggesting that the determination of a country’s influence abroad is far more challenging than the familiar claims we often encounter in the news media and even some scholarly publications. Concerns for making valid inference are no less apposite or compelling for studying China’s international influence as for that of other countries. The analytical issues he raises in this lecture are thus generic and not peculiar to the study of China.

field_description.processed: 洪武元年十二月（1369），明太祖改太史院為司天監。同時，為了提升天文觀測手段的精確度，明太祖重新確立官方天文機構中漢曆、回回曆雙軌制，即在司天監之外另置回回司天監。約在此時，明太祖任命蒙元回回司天監官員阿都刺（‘Abd Allāh）為回回司天少監。洪武三年（1370）六月，明太祖又改司天監為欽天監，下設天文科、漏刻科、《大統曆》科、《回回曆》科等四個單位，同時又改回回司天監為回回欽天監。欽天監中的《回回曆》科並不單獨編印伊斯蘭曆本，而是將推算結果供《大統曆》參用；而回回欽天監則以伊斯蘭方法就曆法中的天文常數進行觀測，製作星表或「立成表」（Zīj）和編印《回回曆》。崇禎二年（1629）五月乙卯朔日食，欽天監預報發生顯著錯誤，改曆之議遂起。當時徐光啟提出改曆方案，七月十四日得到明思宗朱由檢的批准。七月廿六日徐光啟上奏〈條議曆法修正歲差疏〉，提出曆法修正十事、修曆用人三事（包括任用李之藻和耶穌會士鄧玉函【Johannes Schreck-Terrentius, 1576-1630】等中外臣僚、用西法和任用精於測驗推步、製造儀器及善算的人）、急用儀象十事（包括製造七政象限大儀六座、列宿紀限大儀三座、列宿經緯天球儀一架和遠鏡三架等）和度數旁通十事。九月十五日，徐光啟奉敕於北京宣武門內首善書院舊址開設曆局（毗鄰是宣武門北京天主堂），開始修曆工作。本講除析述伊斯蘭科學與耶穌會科學先後在明代中國流播的經緯外，並蠡探明太祖與明思宗對域外傳入之科技文化的態度。

node.title: Reclaiming Recovery: Critical Reflections on the Use of the Recovery Approach in Mental Health and Suicide Prevention among Chinese Communities in the UK and Hong Kong

field_speakers.processed: Dr. Lynn Tang (Department of Sociology and Social Policy, Lingnan University)
field_speakers.value: Dr. Lynn Tang (Department of Sociology and Social Policy, Lingnan University)

field_organizers.processed: Hong Kong Institute for the Humanities and Social Sciences, The University of Hong Kong
field_organizers.value: Hong Kong Institute for the Humanities and Social Sciences, The University of Hong Kong

field_description.processed: The recovery movement originated in the US in the late 1980s, with service users challenging the dominant psychiatric power in mental health system and advocating for seeing recovery as a self-determined journey with self-defined goals. Since then, the concepts of Recovery Approach have been mainstreamed in mental health policies in Anglophone countries. However, its implementation under neoliberalism in these countries has been criticised. This seminar will consist of three parts. First, I will review the debates over the controversy of the Recovery Approach. Second, I will present the findings of a study that explores the way social inequalities shape the journeys of Chinese mental health service users in the UK. Third, based on the debates and empirical research overseas, I will discuss the application of the Recovery Approach in the local context, with a particular focus on suicide prevention in Hong Kong.

node.title: Digital Reading and Online Reading

field_speakers.processed: Duncan Paterson (University of Freiburg), Dylan Suher (University of Hong Kong)
field_speakers.value: Duncan Paterson (University of Freiburg), Dylan Suher (University of Hong Kong)

field_organizers.processed: European Research Council, University of Freiburg, ReadChina research team
field_organizers.value: European Research Council, University of Freiburg, ReadChina research team

field_description.processed: We are living in a world that has been greatly influenced by digital and Internet technologies in various aspects. Reading practices and studies of reading are no exception. In the 6th session of ReadChina's online lectures, Duncan Paterson (data manager of ReadChina) will address the value of new digital approaches (adopted by the ReadChina team) in the study of reading. He will then discuss the impact and potential insights from reading born-digital texts in contemporary China. The second speaker, Dylan Suher, will unfold his studies on “YY fiction” – a prominent genre in the Chinese Internet fiction. Not only will he investigate the outline, the origin and genealogy of YY fiction, he will also suggest a re-reading of the older, allegedly realist novel as a work of YY fiction. For both speakers, digital and Internet technologies offer more than a new field in (the studies of) reading, but can transform our overall perceptions on reading and on literary interpretation.

node.title: Powershift: India - China Relations in a Multipolar World

field_speakers.processed: Dr Zorawar Daulet Singh (NorthCap University), Ananth Krishnan(The Hindu)
field_speakers.value: Dr Zorawar Daulet Singh (NorthCap University), Ananth Krishnan(The Hindu)

field_organizers.processed: Institute of Chinese Studies, Delhi
field_organizers.value: Institute of Chinese Studies, Delhi

field_description.processed:
The equation between India and China is once again poised to influence the future course of Asia just as it did seven decades ago following the 1962 war between them. New frictions and differences are being brought to the fore as India and China pursue their regional interests and attempt to settle old scores. Although both leaderships have managed it delicately, it is questionable whether Delhi and Beijing can maintain such a balancing act for long. The emerging multipolar world has brought the relationship to crossroads where today’s choices will profoundly impact India’s economy, security and the regional order & it is critical that India’s leaders get its China policy right.

Powershift helps make sense of a complex relationship, how India and China are learning to cope with each other’s rise on the world stage and provides much-needed context for Indians to start thinking more strategically and realistically about their largest neighbour.

field_description.processed:
For our December book club, we’ll be reading China’s New Youth (UK edition titled “Wish Lanterns”) in preparation for our chat with the author, Alec Ash.
China’s new youth are the generation that will change China. Offspring of the one-child policy, with no memory of Tiananmen, they are destined to transform both their nation and the world. Understanding their motivations, dreams, and attitudes is possibly the most important gauge of China’s future direction as it plays an increasingly important role in shaping this century.
China’s New Youth follows the lives of six young Chinese as they navigate their aspirations, discontents, politics, and love lives. Their stories include a netizen nationalist, a country migrant, the daughter of a Party member, a rising pop star, and a feminist entrepreneur. With intimate access to this diverse generation, Alec Ash—a young writer based in China since 2012—gives a vivid, immersive, fascinating account of young China as it comes of age.

field_description.processed: What began as yet another face off along the LAC 8 months ago, took an ugly turn with 20 Indian soldiers killed in action on the night of June 14-15. Beijing's frustration is increasing in its inability to manage the crisis with a series of military and diplomatic talks resulting in failures, unlike Doklam. On the other hand, there is near consensus in India that the Galwan Incident marks an inflection point in India’s China policy. At the same time, China hasn't toned down its narrative that it is India’s growing belligerence fueled by its growing intimacy with anti-China forces led by US which is the reason for the unprecedented situation. In recent weeks, since it became increasingly certain that Joe Biden not Trump will move into the White House, there has been an unusual rise in commentaries on India in the Chinese media, an indication that the more China tries to 管控 or “control” India, the harder India touches China's nerve.

node.title: Chinese Family in Transition

field_speakers.processed: Professor Yu Xie (Princeton University)
field_speakers.value: Professor Yu Xie (Princeton University)

field_organizers.processed: Institute of Chinese Studies
field_organizers.value: Institute of Chinese Studies

field_description.processed: The Chinese family has been undergoing a rapid transition in the past few decades, with many of its traditional functions and practices fundamentally changed. We find that union formation in China has trended increasingly towards patterns commonly observed in the West, including delayed ages of marriage and common practices of premarital cohabitation. Despite below-replacement fertility, childlessness remains rare among married Chinese couples. In addition, almost all children are born and raised within marriage, with a virtual absence of non-marital childbearing in China. Although we observe a slight increase in divorce across cohorts, the divorce rate within 10 years in China was much lower than in other East Asian societies. Our research suggests that the Chinese family has been changed by modernization and economic development, but it is still influenced by a Confucian culture.

field_description.processed: On January 7th, 2021, Professor Julia C. Strauss will give a Book Talk on her work, State Formation in China and Taiwan: Bureaucracy, Campaign, and Performance. This book is a comparative study of regime consolidation in the ‘revolutionary’ People’s Republic of China and the ‘conservative’ Republic of China (Taiwan) in the years following the communist victory against the nationalists on the Chinese mainland in 1949. Julia C. Strauss argues that accounting for these two variants of the Chinese state solely in terms of their divergent ideology and institutions fails to recognize their similarities and their relative successes. Focusing on Sunan and Taiwan, Strauss considers state personnel, the use of terror and land reform to explore the evolution of these revolutionary and conservative regimes between 1949 and 1954. node.title: Self-Knowledge as Religious Knowledge: Lottery Divination in Buddhist Temples in Contemporary China

field_speakers.processed: Yang Shen (Cultural Anthropology; Max Planck Institute for the Study of Religious and Ethnic Diversity, Göttingen)
field_speakers.value: Yang Shen (Cultural Anthropology; Max Planck Institute for the Study of Religious and Ethnic Diversity, Göttingen)

field_organizers.processed: International Research Consortium “Fate, Freedom, and Prognostication — Strategies for Coping with the Future in East Asia and Europe," University of Erlangen–Nuremberg
field_organizers.value: International Research Consortium “Fate, Freedom, and Prognostication — Strategies for Coping with the Future in East Asia and Europe," University of Erlangen–Nuremberg

field_description.processed: Qian or lottery divination in Chinese temples is a convenient self-help technique to generate creative self-knowledge. My recent fieldwork in east China indicates that divination-seekers distinguish a lot from a poem. The most critical transformative moment occurs in the ritual action of seeking the lot, by which temple-goers performatively turn themselves into a divine communicator. Interpretive relationships are secondary; they happen between various actors who share the temple spaces contingently and are established case by case through a sequence of entrustment moves. The study develops a ritual attunement approach for re-considering generic participation in Buddhist temples in contemporary China. In a late socialist temple settings where specialized diviners are institutionally excluded, self-help lottery divination gives us a case to rethink the social constitution of religious knowledge.

field_speakers.processed: Paola Iovene (University of Chicago), Eve Lin (University of Freiburg), Nicolai Volland (as discussant, Penn State University)
field_speakers.value: Paola Iovene (University of Chicago), Eve Lin (University of Freiburg), Nicolai Volland (as discussant, Penn State University)

field_organizers.processed: European Research Council, University of Freiburg, ReadChina research team
field_organizers.value: European Research Council, University of Freiburg, ReadChina research team

field_description.processed: Media and places of reading are often seen as the context of reading acts. Foregrounding these “peripheral” aspects of reading, however, will supplement our understandings of reading cultures and the social-cultural mechanisms behind reading. Moreover, analyzing media and places of reading promotes reevaluations of literary figures and literary history, brings into being new forms of reading, and constantly (re-)defines cultural legacies and cultural concepts in a rapid-changing society such as that of the post-Mao China. In the 7th session of ReadChina's online lecture series, Paola Iovene will investigate how local museums and the national radio have recreated the authorial persona of the writer Lu Yao and popularized his fiction beyond the written page. The other speaker, Eve Lin, will discuss the vicissitudes of post-Mao China’s reading culture and its high culture legacy by tracing how the concept of “Avant-Garde” mutates over the years in bookstores.

field_description.processed: The True Story of Ah Q first appeared as a 9-part series in Morning News (晨报), Beijing between Dec 1921 and Feb 1922. Lu Xun, fearing rebuke and rejection from traditional literary scholars, chose Ba Ren (巴人 or commoner) as the pseudonym to hide his identity and protect his literary image. He was overwhelmed when the series became a sensation among people from all walks of life. During the past century, scholars and critics in China, Japan and the West, have relentlessly upheld 'The True Story of Ah Q' as not only Lu Xun’s best but also modern China’s most soul-stirring, most condescending to traditional Confucian values, most politically sensitive, most pro-people, most anti-feudal and anti-rulers, most anti-revolution Revolutionary, most anti-modern Modernist, most anti-Classics classic, most “ordinary” and most tragic work of fiction. This Conference will examine questions which need to be addressed in order to objectively analyse and evaluate Lu Xun, Ah Q, and the future of China.

field_description.processed: Part of the East Asia by the Book! CEAS Author Talks series, this event features Michigan State University's Xuefei Ren, and her book, "Governing the Urban in China and India: Land Grabs, Slum Clearance, and the War on Air Pollution." Urbanization is rapidly overtaking China and India, the two most populous countries in the world. One-sixth of humanity now lives in either a Chinese or Indian city. This transformation has unleashed enormous pressures on land use, housing, and the environment. Despite the stakes, the workings of urban governance in China and India remain obscure and poorly understood. Professor Ren's book explores how the two countries govern their cities and how their different styles of governance produce inequality and exclusion. This program also features University of Chicago's Marco Garrido as Discussant.

node.title: Children in Skipped generation Families in Rural China

field_speakers.processed: Professor Rachel Murphy, University of Oxford
field_speakers.value: Professor Rachel Murphy, University of Oxford

field_organizers.processed: University of Oxford China Centre
field_organizers.value: University of Oxford China Centre

field_description.processed: This seminar draws on a section of Rachel Murphy’s book, The Children of China’s Great Migration (Cambridge University Press, 2020). It explores children’s navigation of their relationship with significant adults in skipped generation families, which is families where both parents worked away in the cities while the children stayed in the countryside in the care of (paternal) grandparents. The analysis adapts Ester Goh’s (2011) concept of ‘intergenerational parenting coalitions’ in seeing the migrant parents and the grandparent caregivers as forming ‘multi-local intergenerational parenting coalitions’. The talk explores heterogeneity in children’s experiences of growing up in these skipped generation families.

node.title: Stealthy Reading and Collective Reading in the Mao Era

field_speakers.processed: Eddy U (UC Davis), Damian Mandzunowski (University of Freiburg), Jennifer Altehenger (Oxford University, as discussant)
field_speakers.value: Eddy U (UC Davis), Damian Mandzunowski (University of Freiburg), Jennifer Altehenger (Oxford University, as discussant)

field_organizers.processed: European Research Council, University of Freiburg, ReadChina research team
field_organizers.value: European Research Council, University of Freiburg, ReadChina research team

field_description.processed: In the Mao-era, multifaceted strategies of reading were existing next to one another. The eighth session of the ReadChina online lecture series will explore two such poles on the spectrum of reading acts. On the one side are hidden readings of suppressed or even forbidden texts during the radical phase of the Cultural Revolution. On the other side are officially organized group reading sessions in the mid-1970s. The first speaker, Prof. Eddy U investigates stealthy reading of books, letters, poems, and other material practiced by victims of abuse during the Cultural Revolution for purposes of self-preservation. The second speaker, Damian Mandzunowski, analyses depictions of collective reading activities in posters and photographs created during a mass-reading campaign in 1975 to explore their integrative aspects. Both forms of reading are crucial to take into account when researching the history of reading in the Mao era.

node.title: Maverick or Modern: Gong Zizhen (1792 -1841) and the Origins of Buddhist Studies

field_speakers.processed: Lang Chen (University of Michigan)
field_speakers.value: Lang Chen (University of Michigan)

field_organizers.processed: Lieberthal-Rogel Center for Chinese Studies
field_organizers.value: Lieberthal-Rogel Center for Chinese Studies

field_description.processed: While Gong Zizhen (1792-1841) has been acclaimed as a patriotic poet and a prophet of revolutions and modernity in China, his Buddhist thoughts and practices have often been either overlooked or misunderstood. Why did Gong profess his devotion to Tiantai Buddhism in particular, and yet why did he choose to criticize the Lotus Sutra, the most sacred scripture for Tiantai? This research investigates Gong's unique Buddhism in relation to modern religiosity and modern Buddhist Studies.

node.title: Starting Over in Meiji Japan: the Lives of a Former Samurai and his Ex-Concubine

field_speakers.processed: Marnie S. Anderson (Department of History, Smith College, Massachusetts)
field_speakers.value: Marnie S. Anderson (Department of History, Smith College, Massachusetts)

field_organizers.processed: East Asia Center at UC Santa Barbara
field_organizers.value: East Asia Center at UC Santa Barbara

field_description.processed: This talk examines the lives of two reform-minded individuals during Japan’s Meiji period (1868-1912): Nakagawa Yokotarō (1836-1903) and Sumiya Koume (1850-1920). I contend that this era of rapid modernization and social upheaval offered each of them a new start and the chance to create a new identity. In 1868, Nakagawa, a samurai bureaucrat bought out Sumiya’s geisha contract and made her his concubine. After moving in with Nakagawa and his wife, Sumiya gave birth to a daughter. Nakagawa then became interested in Christianity, and he sent Sumiya to Kobe College, an institution run by western missionaries. Ultimately, Sumiya decided that concubinage was sinful, converted to Christianity, and left Nakagawa, leading him to complain that “Jesus stole my mistress.” After their breakup, both played prominent roles as local reformers. Together their stories shed light on how individuals in late nineteenth-century Japan forged new gender roles and created a new world.

node.title: US-China Relations under Biden Administration: Implications for India

field_speakers.processed: Ambassador Arun K. Singh (Emory University), Mr Ananth Krishnan (The Hindu Newspaper)
field_speakers.value: Ambassador Arun K. Singh (Emory University), Mr Ananth Krishnan (The Hindu Newspaper)

field_organizers.processed: Institute of Chinese Studies Delhi India
field_organizers.value: Institute of Chinese Studies Delhi India

field_description.processed:
As US transitions to a Biden Presidency, there is inevitable anxiety among countries at the receiving end of China's unilateral assertions based on its accrued strength. For decades, especially since 1979, US policy was "engagement" with China in the belief that this would lead to political and economic liberalization. The Deng-articulated policy of "hide and bide" did not challenge this assumption directly. The Obama-Biden administration, from 2009- 2016, struggled to find the right approach, moving from "strategic reassurance" to "pivot" & then "rebalance". The Trump Administration initially vacillated, but later defined China as a rival, and ratcheted up tariff, technology denial, and other restrictions.

Would a Biden Administration build further on the Trump-era characterization of China as rival, predator, authoritarian; or would it be conditioned more by the search for common ground? This Webinar tries to answer several such questions.

node.title: The Great Asian Deerskin Boom: Trade, War and the Early Modern Japanese Consumer

field_speakers.processed: Adam Clulow (University of Texas at Austin)
field_speakers.value: Adam Clulow (University of Texas at Austin)

field_organizers.processed: University of Chicago Center for East Asian Studies
field_organizers.value: University of Chicago Center for East Asian Studies

field_description.processed: Part of the CEAS Lecture Series, this event features University of Texas at Austin's, Adam Clulow. During the early modern period, the deerskin trade stretched across East/Southeast Asia, binding hunters/merchants/consumers together in sprawling networks. Propelled by a voracious demand for soft/pliable leather, hundreds of thousands of skins were shipped out each year from Ayutthaya (Siam), Cambodia and Taiwan to Japan. The scale of the trade meant that it became a driver for change and conflict along each stage of the wider commodity chain. The relentless demand for deerskins prompted environmental devastation as hunting grounds were depleted or completely hunted out. In ports across the region, the deerskin trade became a site of ferocious competition between Asian and European merchants for control over this important commodity. Read more by clicking on the associated link.

node.title: Impact of a Labor Income Reward Plan: An Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) Experiment in China

field_speakers.processed: Li Gan
field_speakers.value: Li Gan

field_organizers.processed: Columbia China Center for Social Policy, Columbia University Weatherhead East Asian Institute, Columbia School of Social Work, Center on Poverty and Social Policy at Columbia University.
field_organizers.value: Columbia China Center for Social Policy, Columbia University Weatherhead East Asian Institute, Columbia School of Social Work, Center on Poverty and Social Policy at Columbia University.

field_description.processed: China currently has no in-work benefit nor social welfare programs such as the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) in the United States. Yet, the literature and global evidence have suggested EITC-type programs’ potentials on poverty alleviation and work incentives. This study examines the first-ever EITC field experiment in China with strong treatment intensity (20% of household monthly income) and rigorous validation procedure. The two-year experiment on 259 households shows that the participation of the program increases employment by 0.33 person (14%) and monthly working hours by 81 hours (40%) per household. We also find significant increases in household earnings and expenditures. These effects are substantially larger than the existing literature partially because of the strong treatment intensity. Our study contributes to a large literature that studies the effect of in-work benefits.

field_speakers.value: Mareike Ohlberg (Senior Fellow, Asia Program, The German Marshall Fund of the United States), Jessica Batke (Senior Editor, ChinaFile, Center on U.S.-China Relations, Asia Society)

field_organizers.processed: 21st Century China Center, UC San Diego School of Global Policy & Strategy
field_organizers.value: 21st Century China Center, UC San Diego School of Global Policy & Strategy

field_description.processed: Mareike Ohlberg of The German Marshall Fund and Jessica Batke of ChinaFile present their analysis of 76,000 Chinese government records that document the rise and widespread procurement of surveillance technology and services over the last 16 years. Their research show that despite extreme levels of surveillance in the Xinjiang Uighur Autonomous Region, the same schemes in use in Xinjiang are also being used across the country from large cities to small towns. Whether they are assessing residents’ basic needs or trying to predict future behavior, officials engaged in surveillance are pursuing a single goal: to keep China’s citizens under near-constant watch. This webinar will be moderated by UC San Diego professor Victor Shih.
